./.title: Introduction
./.body:
Made In a Fab Lab Project XXXX
Project Summary
Project support documentation

Requirements
Business Canvas
Product pitch
Team
Production plan
Marketing plan
Licensing
Funding strategy

Product documentation

Product design
Mockups and prototypes
Bill of materials
Assembly instructions
Marketing material
Splash Website

Customer documentation

User manual
FAQ

requirements.html.title: Requirements
requirements.html.body:
Product requirements
Purpose and scope
From both a technical and business perspective
(100 words)
Stakeholder identification
List the stakeholders and give a short description for each
(50 words each)
Market assessment - target demographics
Describe which categories your target customers fall 

Category 1 - Age - Sex - Other characteristics

Product overview
Describe the product in more detail, add sketches and any other
reference to existing products you might have taken inspiration from
Use cases
An use case is a list of actions or event steps typically defining the interactions between a person and an object.
Define the actors and systems, i.e. the people and machines or objects involved in your product, then use them in use cases.
i.e. 

Operator
Computer

Use case 1
Define your use case in short simple phrases, one per line.
Here an example:
Title: Turning on the power
Actions: The operator pushes the power button 
Outcomes: 

A red light on the button turns on.
The computer turns on.

(about 200 words per use case)
Requirements
From the use cases above you should be able to extract functional and usability requirements
Functional requirements
What the product should do
Usability requirements
Details to make the product more close to the user
Technical requirements
Any requirement that must be satisfied at a technical level, i.e. button with embedded light

canvas.html.title: Business Canvas
canvas.html.body:
Business model
Define your overall business model. How you will cover production costs, what sales you could reasonably expect, etc.
To help you identify the business model you can draft a preliminary Business model canvas.
The source is in the assets/canvas folder.

pitch.html.title: Product pitch
pitch.html.body:
Pitch
From Forbes:
"Your pitch will come in handy in more ways than one. Youâ€™ll use it in meetings with investors. Youâ€™ll use it when recruiting talent. Youâ€™ll use it when you tell your friends and family why they should support you in this exciting endeavor. Your pitch should be a very concise PowerPoint presentation that tells your vision for the business and the strategy youâ€™ll use to achieve it. Refining a pitch to get it right often takes time. Once you have a solid version, it is important to continue fine-tuning it as you receive feedback from investors."
    AirBnB Pitch Deck   from PitchDeckCoach 
Elevator pitch

team.html.title: Team
team.html.body:
Team members
Describe the team members, each has his own experience and background. This makes the project more personal.

Founders - Key Roles
Name, CEO
Name, CTO
Name, CFO
Name, Marketing & Communication
Advisors
Name, Company

production.html.title: Production plan
production.html.body:
Production plan
Plan the development and production of your project using either GANTT charts or Khan ban boards.
Gantt chart Template
The following spreadsheet can be used as a template for your GANTT chart.
Kan Ban Board
You can use Trello for planning your projects. In alternative you can also try Google Keep, or use post-its on the wall.

licensing.html.title: Licensing
licensing.html.body:
Licensing strategy
Choose one or multiple licenses for your product. 
Identify and avoid if possible parts of it that are covered by patents and you need to license from other companies.
If this is foreseen outline how individuals could contribute to your product, for example making a variant or adding content for it, and how you could license your product to other companies.

funding.html.title: Funding strategy
funding.html.body:
Funding strategy
Make a small balance sheet for your product: 

Identify how much money you need in order to produce it and deliver a first batch to your customers.

Identify how will you find this money, including personal funding, friends and family, pre-orders, crowdfunding, investors, loans, etc.


Repeat the project including time information, so you can find out how much resources you need during each period, for example each quarter in an year.
Funding strategy example
Costs                               Q1  Q2  Q3  Q4 ...

Materials & parts            
Equipment & tools
Staff
Consultants
Marketing
Other

Total costs: ....
Funding sources

Personal investment
Other investors
Pre-orders
Crowdfunding
Banks

Total funding: ....

design.html.title: Product design
design.html.body:
Product design
Your project needs to be fully reproducible from these files. 
Please make sure also to link source files and include the file size to the page like this:

Source file STL (32mb) 

You can embed nice previews using different platforms, for example Sketchfab allows the preview below:



    Subaru Outback Engine Long Block
    by Matthew Brennan
    on Sketchfab

prototypes.html.title: Mockups and prototypes
prototypes.html.body:
Prototypes
Document here your prototypes, describe the technical components, and the production process.
Ideally you should be able to document what changed at every revision so you can recover solutions found to improve the
prototype.
Mockups
Insert here preliminary sketches you made before starting the prototyping process


Version 0.1 - Date - First prototype
Materials used
Processes used

bom.html.title: Bill of materials
bom.html.body:
Bill of materials
List each external part composing your product, and make a separate section for each part you should produce.
Copy and replace the google sheet below to start.
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ISiyK6udh7EOn_oku_92RvVcILSkK3ziw_Ozz3F0Fwc/edit?usp=sharing
Go to Publish in google docs to generate a new embedding code

assembly.html.title: Assembly instructions
assembly.html.body:
Assembly instructions
Ideally you should be able to document the process of assembling your product in a very detailed and understandable way.
Not all people who will work on your product have the technical knowledge to understand how it works, so the assembly manual should be simple enough to allow them to complete their work.
A great example are IKEA Assembly manuals

marketing_materials.html.title: Marketing material
marketing_materials.html.body:
Marketing materials
In order to be able to communicate and market your product you will need to define a brand and some visual elements for it.
Product logo & Branding

Product banner

Website graphics

Product shots

manual.html.title: User manual
manual.html.body:
Manual
Create a one page manual for your product, describing the main features and how to operate it.
Make it easy to read and yet complete of all the required parts.
Add pictures and illustration to make it less boring.

faq.html.title: FAQ
faq.html.body:
Customer FAQ
Write here the questions that you received about your project,
then answer them in a satisfactory way. 
They will help answering common questions by customers.
Question text
Answer text
Question text
Answer text
Question text
Answer text
